channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8545] Meta stuck in transition when it is assigned to a just restarted dead region sever
item.description:
Support the meta region server is down, and the SSH tries to re-assign it. This could happen:

1. AM plans to assign meta to a region server (R_old);
2. Now R_old is dead, the new region server (R_new) starts up on the same host, port, but gets a different start code;
3. AM sends the open region request to R_new and the Meta is opened on it;
4. AM gets ZK event, but it is from a different region server instance (R_new), not the expected one (R_old), so it sends a close region request to R_new;
5. Now, the meta is stuck in transition and won't be assigned.

This won't happen to a user region since the SSH for R_old will find out the user region stuck in transition and re-assign it. For meta, it is a little different. AM checks if a dead region server carries the meta based on the ZK info, which is changed to the new region server R_new at step 3 by the open region handler.

The fix I was thinking about is:
1. In checking if a region server carries a region, uses the region transition information if it exists (which is the source of truth, to master), if not, checks the ZK data as before;
2. In open region handler, when transition assign zk node from offline to opening, make sure the current region server is the expected one (ZK#transitionNode, existing code doesn't check the target server name).
item.summary: Meta stuck in transition when it is assigned to a just restarted dead region sever

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Attached a patch. The fix is to make sure the server where region transition happens doesn't change. Added a test case to fake a dead region server restarted quickly, and region open on the dead server should fail.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12583407/trunk-8545.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 6 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

-1 core tests. The patch failed these unit tests:
org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.TestMasterFailover
org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.TestMasterShutdown

Looking into the test failures.
Attached v2 which fixed one unit test by restoring the region plan in case a region was opening.

against trunk revision .

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5726//console

This message is automatically generated.

@Jimmy
Going thro the logs 


[main] master.ServerManager(736): New admin connection to RSVASUDE-MOBL.gar.corp.intel.com,52745,1368765576099

2013-05-17 10:09:54,939 INFO  [PRI IPC Server handler 0 on 52745] regionserver.HRegionServer(3456): Received request to open region: testAssignRegionOnRestartedServer,A,1368765580368.4c096a61387cfc7d63df0be881875f03. on RSVASUDE-MOBL.gar.corp.intel.com,52745,1368765576199

The server ending with 099 is the dead server and the server ending with 199 is the actual new alive server. So should we validate this on the RS side and make it FAILED_OPEN so that master can carry out the assignment with a new plan. This is a case where an old server goes down and a new server immediately comes up in the same node.

ramkrishna.s.vasudevan, thanks for the review.

In patch v2, we just fail the region open, but don't change the znode to FAILED_OPEN. So the SSH of the dead server will pick it up and assign it. If we move it to FAILED_OPEN, AM could be a little fast in assigning it. However, this will be racing with SSH. It also violates our assumption that only the target server can transition the znode. I think for now we can keep it simple and not to make it FAILED_OPEN because this scenario is rare.

I like tightening up our inspection of an event such that now we also check source server, not just even type. Thats good. If there are probs. in AM, this will help expose them the sooner.

When we return -1 out of zkassign, what will the caller do? Stop processing the assign?

Is this a bug fix?

  • SERVERNAME_A, EventType.M_ZK_REGION_OFFLINE,
    + SERVERNAME_B, EventType.M_ZK_REGION_OFFLINE,

Patch looks good to me otherwise.

When we return -1 out of zkassign, what will the caller do? Stop processing the assign?

Yes, the assignment processing is aborted on that region server, since it is not the server meant to open the region per AM.

Is this a bug fix?

Yes, that's an existing bug. Once we tighten things up, this bug showed up. It is just a testing issue though.
I am +1 (I'd put more weight in a +1 from ramkrishna.s.vasudevan though).

ramkrishna.s.vasudevan, if we need to move the znode to failed_open, we should be sure that region server is really dead. We can be so sure only if the target region server is the same as this one, with an old time stamp.

Ok, so i get your point. Yes we have to go with the timestamp which is to be compared if it has an older one.
But going through the code, when we do sendRegionOpen() we try to get the connection to the server as per the destination server in the plan.
Suppose it is the new server with latest timestamp. We try to get the connection and from the 


 AdminService.BlockingInterface admin = this.rsAdmins.get(sn);

Here ServerName equals() method uses the compareTo which internally uses the startCode also. So ideally we would not get any connection from the rsAdmins.
So we will try to form a new connection to the server but this time considering only the new hostname and port and without including the start code. So this will give a connection to the new RS with latest startcode. As attached in the log message above the Servername printed is confusing when you see the startcode of it.
So if we are not able to do this validation on the RS side as we are not aware of the older timestamp we may have to compare the start code of the new connection and the one in the plan and throw an exception saying ServerNotRunningYetException. What do you say Jimmy.

In HConnectionImpl we are already trying to do this if the start code does not match


      if (isDeadServer(serverName)) {

        throw new RegionServerStoppedException(serverName + " is dead.");

      }

When we run the attached test case 


      if (clusterStatusListener == null) {

        return false;

      }

This is what is happening and so we are creating a new connection every time. Ideally we should ensure that we don't create the connection to the new RS as the original request is for a dead RS.

Going thro the code once again, it is bit difficult to know whether the new connection is to the same server but with different host or entirely a new server.
If the below code 


      if (isDeadServer(serverName)) {

        throw new RegionServerStoppedException(serverName + " is dead.");

      }

works then things will be fine. Will see if anything can be done here if not we can go with the current patch itself.

This is a very rare racing issue. It really depends how thing happens at that moment. Since the region plan uses the old server, it means isDeadServer(serveName) could return false, while the server is already dead because there is a short time in the middle.

Attached version v3 which has a little change to make sure most of the error messages are the same as before (the patch). Since when a version mismatches, or the etype mismatches, most likely, the region server name doesn't match. There is no logic change here.

Ideally we should ensure that we don't create the connection to the new RS as the original request is for a dead RS.

I agree. However, this is hard because we probably don't have a cached connection (especially when master fails over), while the master hasn't detected the region server is already restarted.

+1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12583854/trunk-8545_v3.patch
against trunk revision .

This message is automatically generated.

+1 Jimmy. It is difficult to find out whether the new connection is to a new RS that got restarted. Lets get this patch in for now.
Good work.
Integrated into trunk and 0.95. Thanks Ram and Stack for the review.

Integrated in hbase-0.95 #208 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/hbase-0.95/208/)

Result = SUCCESS
